Add a property to a JavaScript object using a variable as the name?
How does the Java 'for each' loop work?

561: <p>It's implied by <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/85190/how-does-the-java-for-each-loop-work/85206#85206">nsayer's answer</a>, but it's worth noting that the OP's for(..) syntax will work when "someList" is <em>anything</em> that implements java.lang.Iterable -- it doesn't have to be a list, or some collection from java.util. Even your own types, therefore, can be used with this syntax.</p>

<p>Also note that using the "foreach" method in the original question does have some limitations, such as not being able to remove items from the list during the iteration.</p>

<p>The new for-loop is easier to read and removes the need for a separate iterator, but is only really usable in read-only iteration passes.</p>

<p>The Java for-each idiom can only be applied to arrays or objects of type <strong>*Iterable</strong>. This idiom is <strong><em>implicit</em></strong> as it truly backed by an Iterator. The Iterator is programmed by the programmer and often uses an integer index or a node (depending on the data structure) to keep track of its position. On paper it is slower than a regular for-loop, a least for "linear" structures like arrays and Lists but it provides greater abstraction. </p>
